content.description: Just left of McKinley's Crack is this deceiving face climb.  It isn't hard, but looks really easy.  Small holds are the problem and the solution.
content.protection: 2 chains at the top.  4 bolts on the route.

content.description: In the gully west of the Gully of Higher Education is a nice finger/hand crack that faces west.  It is visible from the road.  It looks uglier than it really is.  Finger locks and happiness abound at this location.  The book gives this a 5.7 rating.
content.protection: 1 chain at the top.  Bring a large nut to set up the anchors.  It protects well with large to medium gear

content.description: Even further left on a south-facing steep face is this route.  It is visible from the road.  A hard first clip leads to a pair of dynos.  Clip #2 and the climbing eases up.  A pump.
content.protection: 2 chains at the top.  4 bolts on the route.  One odd-looking hanger??

content.description: Almost a scramble on juggy, fairly solid rock that's surprisingly steep for how moderate/easy the climbing is.
content.protection: Standard Rack.  No anchor on the top but a short traverse to the top of McKinley's Crack yields a fixed anchor there.
content.location:
Located to the right of "McKinley's Crack".  Milk the juggy weaknesses through a couple of horizontal shallow ledges and cracks.

Either down climb and walk off the back side or traverse to the climber's left to the anchor on McKinley's Crack.
